title: How are rocks useful to us? - Quora

response.answer_text: Human Beings have a very healthy relationship with Rocks from ancient history till date, some people called Petrologist even ‘Date' rocks, literally. Before the first metal (copper) was known to man, Rocks were the only hard substance used for different purposes. The periods of usage of rocks has been studied under three sections namely Paleolithic (Old Stone age), Mesolithic (Middle Stone age), and Neolithic (New Stone age). Later Copper was discovered and the Chalcolithic age started. Early human used rocks for hunting, shaping softer rock with harder ones, making spear tips, sharp-pointed hammer type tools for piercing skull of animals, flat-edged rocks for cutting flesh and other stuffs as such. The usage of rocks has a total different perspective in modern days and it has improved gradually and slowly. Buildings are entirely made of Rocks, for instance, The Taj Mahal (made up of white marble, a metamorphic rock), floor are decorated with polished igneous rocks such as granites, railway tracks are laid down by billions of tonnes of Basalt, flat slate and sandstone slabs are laid down for roofing buildings, etc. etc. in construction. Besides what I have mentioned, rocks of economic importance contains expensive minerals such as corondum which finds its application as hard abrasive material and as Gemstone (ruby, sapphire). Limestone a sedimentary rock which is a prime constituent of Cement, Coal - the combustible rock, In fact we eat Rock everyday in the form of Salt which is nothing but a rock called Halite. One could go on writing about the use of Rocks by man but I would like to end up with a quote “When a king reigns it is thanks to the people, when a river sings it is thanks to the stones”. Malagasy. Hope I did justice to your question. Thank you.

Do you live in a building? The walls, the roof, the interior walls, the floor, the lights, the electrical wiring, the appliances, even the toilet and tub, are produced from mining rocks and minerals. Do you drive a car? The metals it is made of, and even the plastics it is made of, and the gas it runs on - or the battery it runs on, if it is electric - are all produced from mining rocks and minerals. Your phone, your computer, your television, the satellites that allow for cellular phones and internet - all, everything they are made of, are produced from mining rocks and minerals. Your toothpaste, your plates, your utensils, the metal in your belt and shoes, the plastic in your shoes, the nylon involved in your clothes, your socks, your shoes, your camping tent…all these are produced from mining rocks and minerals. If you cannot grow it from a plant, it has to be mined from rocks and minerals.

The importance of rocks are as follows : Like minerals rocks are of great resource value some directly and some as important as constituents of rocks.Soils are derived from the weathering of the rocks.Almost all types of building material are used for paving roads, floors or building walls of houses including bridges come from rocks.Rocks are a source of precious metals like gold,silver, platinum etcApart from minerals and fossil fuels rock wastes have now been used in manufacturing various articles.

Rocks are very useful to us because : ◆ Like minerals, rocks are of great resource value, some directly and some as constituents of minerals. ◆ Soils are derived from weathering of rocks. ◆ Almost all types of building materials used for paving roads, floors or building walls of houses or various other structures including bridges come from rocks. ◆ Rocks are a source of precious metals like gold, silver, platinum, etc. ◆ Apart from minerals and fossil fuels, even rock wastes have now been used in manufacturing various articles.

We are constructed from many such stone elements, such as carbon, phosphorus and calcium that make up many minerals found in stones. In addition to being composed of stones, we consume plants that grow from these stones ground over millennia into soil. Every step we take is upon this Earth. Every waking moment, we are near them, are them and consume what grows from them. Our water contains many minerals as well, even after standard filtration. More than that, our economies revolve around silicon information networks and gold. We used to trade heavily in gold, but now it even makes up the most important calculation devices on the planet instead. It is still worn and regularly given as a sign of eternal love, one of our highest cultural virtues. That is why rocks are important to humans. How? Well, it would be very hard to avoid it living here, and why would we try to?

Aside from what we learned from rocks in scientific terms, we've also learned something very important about rocks which many of us have learned at a young age… but the kids today seem to be missing out on because they're not outside nearly as much as myself and older generations were. So, what is this knowledge of rocks that I'm talking about? It's the knowledge that any good sized rock, sometimes no bigger than a pebble, when traveling at high velocities, causes excruciating pain when making clean contact with any part of your face!!!!

They keep everything from falling to the center of the earth. More seriously, they encode information about the history and processes of the earth. Sedimentary rocks record the history of life on earth, and the history of earth’s surface conditions.Igneous rocks tell us about internal processes and plate motions.Metamorphic rocks record temperature and pressure in the earth, and crustal movements.

Any question about the “importance” of something can have many interpretations. You might want to narrow it down a bit. Many related questions have been posted elsewhere on Quora. See: Why are igneous rocks important? Why are metamorphic rocks important? Why are sedimentary rocks of great importance to humans? What are the uses of rocks and minerals? And there is more. Specific rock formations have a symbolic or historical value in many cultures. They are “important” for very different reasons to some people.

Rocks are usually the source of critical sol nutrients and are freed by weathering of the rock. Minerals including iron, copper, selenium, all necessary and some toxic in excess as well. No rocks, essentially no ecology.

All of them. We extract minerals from certain rock ores. We build th efoundations of our roads and railbeds from crushed rock. Our houses all sit on cement which is crushed limestone, while our great buildings and monuments, even our gravestones, are made of granite and marble. We burn coal and use silica for solar panels and computers. In short, despite our impressive level of technology, we are still living in te Stone Age.
